I am calling JUnit from a task within ant (xml provided below). When I
run ant for my entire suite of tests, I get output which looks like this:

    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 1.979 sec
    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 0.572 sec
    [junit] Testcase: testRun took 0.451 sec
    ...

The problem here is that I have different suites containing tests with
the same name. My setup is an extensive hierarchy of tests where each
subdirectory contains an AllTests class calling addTestSuite for each
of the tests within the same directory and addTest for each AllTests
class in the first level of subdirectories. For example:

    suite.addTest(test.com.sitepak.subdir.AllTests.suite());
    suite.addTestSuite(test.com.sitepak.SSHTest.class);

I have tried many approaches to solve this problem but none have been
satisfactory:

1. I tried overriding the PlainJUnitResultFormatter class, giving my
own implementation of the methods defined in the JUnitResultFormatter
interface. Problem is, startTestSuite is only called once when running
all the AllTests test in the root directory. The reason is probably
that when I call addTest and then addTestSuite, the tests are all
being cumulated in what is considered the same suite.

2. I then tried overridig the XMLJUnitResultFormatter, as stated in
some of the posting in this newsgroup. Once filtered through an XSLT
file, I'm sure I could get the name of the test and its corresponding
class in the same line in a nicely formatted HTML file. However, I
need immediate feedback when calling ant from the command line.

3. I finally tried calling each test individually, as suggested in the
JUnit or Ant FAQ. This consists of providing the following XML in ant:

  <batchtest fork="yes">
    <fileset dir="${src.tests}">
      <include name="**/*Test*.java"/>
      <exclude name="**/AllTests.java"/>
    </fileset>
  </batchtest>

The problem with this approach is that tests are run individually
which makes it impossible to print a summary of the number of tests
which have failed during the run.

If anyone has other suggestions, please let me know. Here is context
information which might be useful:

Ant target:

  <target name="run_tests" depends="init">
    <property name="testcase" value="test.com.sitepak.AllTests"/>
    <junit printSummary="yes" fork="on">
      <classpath refid="classpath.run"/>
      <jvmarg value="-Xmx128m"/>
      <formatter type="plain" usefile="false"/>
      <test name="${testcase}"/>
    </junit>
  </target>

Versions:

  JUnit 3.8.1
  Ant 1.6
  Linux 2.4.21
